name: OECD Privacy Guidelines
description: Non-binding principles by OECD for personal data protection including collection limitation, data quality, purpose specification, use limitation, and security safeguards. Originally issued in 1980 and updated in 2013. Influenced many national laws.

name: Council of Europe Convention 108+
description: The first binding international treaty on data privacy. It sets principles for data protection and requires signatory countries to enact privacy legislation. Open to global participation beyond Council of Europe members.
jurisdiction: Council of Europe and other signatories

name: United Nations Human Rights
description: Privacy is recognized as a human right under international law (UDHR Art. 12, ICCPR Art. 17), establishing an international norm for data protection.

name: APEC Privacy Framework & Cross-Border Privacy Rules (CBPR)
description: A voluntary framework developed by APEC to facilitate cross-border data flows while protecting personal information. Includes mechanisms like CBPR for certifying business compliance. Adopted by 21 member economies including the US, Canada, Japan, and Singapore.

name: California Consumer Privacy Act (CCPA) / California Privacy Rights Act (CPRA)
description: A state law granting California residents rights over personal data, including rights to notice, access, deletion, and opt-out of sale. Imposes transparency and security obligations on businesses handling Californians' data. CCPA effective 2020, amended and expanded by CPRA effective 2023.

name: Health Insurance Portability and Accountability Act (HIPAA)
description: A federal law enacted in 1996 with Privacy and Security Rules to protect individuals’ medical records and other personal health information. Applies to healthcare providers, insurers, and their business associates.

name: Gramm-Leach-Bliley Act (GLBA)
description: A U.S. federal law enacted in 1999 that requires financial institutions to explain their information-sharing practices and to safeguard sensitive data. Mandates privacy notices and secure handling of consumers' financial information.

name: Children’s Online Privacy Protection Act (COPPA)
description: A federal law that protects the personal information of children under 13 online. Requires parental consent for data collection and imposes security and data minimization requirements on child-directed websites and services.

name: U.S. State Privacy Laws
description: Various state-level privacy laws (e.g., Virginia CDPA, Colorado Privacy Act) modeled after California’s CCPA/CPRA. These laws provide rights to residents over personal data and impose compliance obligations on businesses operating in those states.

name: General Data Protection Regulation (GDPR)
description: An EU-wide regulation enacted in 2018 to protect personal data of individuals. It enforces requirements such as lawful bases for processing, explicit consent, data subject rights, and breach notifications. Non-compliance can result in fines up to 4% of global annual turnover. Applies extraterritorially to any organization processing EU residents' data.

name: ePrivacy Directive
description: An EU directive from 2002 governing privacy in electronic communications, including cookies, email marketing, and metadata. Requires user consent for tracking technologies and ensures the confidentiality of communications. Scheduled to be replaced by the proposed ePrivacy Regulation.

name: EU-U.S. Data Privacy Framework
description: A 2023 transatlantic agreement allowing data transfers from the EU to certified U.S. organizations, recognizing U.S. safeguards as adequate under the GDPR. Replaces the invalidated Privacy Shield and allows participating companies to self-certify adherence to EU privacy principles.

name: UK GDPR & Data Protection Act 2018
description: Post-Brexit UK data protection regime mirroring the EU GDPR with UK-specific amendments. It ensures continuity of GDPR principles, such as lawfulness, transparency, and data subject rights, with enforcement by the Information Commissioner’s Office (ICO). Non-compliance can result in substantial fines.

name: Privacy and Electronic Communications Regulations (PECR)
description: UK regulations similar to the EU ePrivacy Directive, governing the use of cookies, direct marketing, and consent requirements for electronic communications.

name: Personal Information Protection and Electronic Documents Act (PIPEDA)
description: A federal law enacted in 2000 regulating data privacy in the private sector across Canada (except in provinces with similar laws). PIPEDA mandates consent, limits collection, and grants individuals rights to access and correct their personal data.

name: Provincial Privacy Laws
description: Several provinces, such as Alberta, British Columbia, and Québec, have their own private-sector privacy acts (e.g., Alberta PIPA, B.C. PIPA, Québec’s Law 25), which largely align with PIPEDA/GDPR principles and apply instead of PIPEDA within those provinces.

name: Privacy Act (Canada)
description: A federal law governing the personal data practices of Canadian government agencies in the public sector. Ensures citizens' right to access and correct their personal data held by federal government bodies.

name: Personal Information Protection Law (PIPL)
description: Enacted in 2021, China's comprehensive data protection law similar to the GDPR. Requires consent or legal basis for data processing, mandates security measures, imposes data localization for certain sensitive data, and regulates cross-border data transfers.

name: Data Security Law (DSL)
description: China’s 2021 law that categorizes data based on national security and economic importance. Imposes localization, risk monitoring, and security assessment requirements for cross-border transfers of important data.

name: Cybersecurity Law
description: Enacted in 2017, this foundational Chinese law introduced requirements for data protection, cybersecurity, and data localization for Critical Information Infrastructure (CII) operators.

name: Digital Personal Data Protection Act (DPDP Act)
description: India's comprehensive privacy law enacted in 2023. Establishes consent-based processing, data subject rights, and rules for cross-border data transfers. Enforced by a Data Protection Board with penalties for violations.

name: Information Technology Act & SPDI Rules
description: Legacy Indian data protection regime under IT Act 2000 and 2011 SPDI Rules. Protected sensitive data (e.g. financial, health), requiring consent and security practices. Remains applicable until full DPDP Act rollout.

name: Cert-In Rules
description: 2022 regulations from Indian CERT requiring breach reporting within 6 hours and log retention for certain entities. Strengthens operational data governance and cybersecurity oversight.

name: Act on Protection of Personal Information (APPI)
description: Japan’s main privacy law, amended in 2020. Applies to all businesses processing personal data. Requires purpose limitation, notice, data subject rights, and restricts cross-border transfers. Japan has EU adequacy since 2019.

name: Personal Information Protection Act (PIPA)
description: South Korea’s comprehensive privacy law (2011, amended 2020). Requires consent for data use, breach notification, and data minimization. Enforced by PIPC. Includes strict cross-border and localization rules. EU adequacy since 2021.

name: Personal Data Protection Act (PDPA)
description: Singapore’s private-sector privacy law (2012, updated 2020). Requires consent or deemed consent, purpose notification, and security safeguards. Introduced breach notification and consent exceptions in latest updates.

name: Personal Data (Privacy) Ordinance (PDPO)
description: Hong Kong’s foundational privacy law enacted in 1995. Sets out data protection principles and provides a complaints mechanism through the Privacy Commissioner.

name: Privacy Act
description: Australia’s federal privacy law enacted in 1988, featuring the Australian Privacy Principles (APPs). Covers both public and private sectors. Currently under review for modernization (as of 2025).

name: Personal Data Protection Act (PDPA)
description: Thailand’s 2022 privacy law modeled on the GDPR. Requires consent for data collection and grants rights to access, correction, and deletion.

name: Lei Geral de Proteção de Dados (LGPD)
description: Brazil’s comprehensive data protection law (2018, effective 2020) inspired by GDPR. Applies to data processing in Brazil or involving Brazilian data subjects. Requires lawful basis, data subject rights, breach notification, and establishes the ANPD as regulator.

name: Federal Law on Protection of Personal Data Held by Private Parties
description: Mexico’s 2010 privacy law governing private-sector data practices. Requires consent for processing, provides ARCO rights, mandates privacy notices and security safeguards. Enforced by the INAI.

name: Personal Data Protection Act (Law 25,326)
description: Argentina’s data protection law enacted in 2000, one of the earliest GDPR-style laws. Requires consent, legitimate purpose, and grants rights to access, rectify, and delete data. Recognized by the EU as providing adequate protection.

name: Regional Data Protection Laws
description: Several Latin American countries including Chile, Colombia (Law 1581), Peru (Law 29733), and Uruguay have implemented or modernized privacy laws aligned with international standards. Chile and Uruguay have received EU adequacy decisions.

name: Financial Action Task Force (FATF) Recommendations
description: FATF’s 40 Recommendations, along with 11 additional provisions on countering proliferation financing, form the global standard for AML/CFT compliance. They cover criminalization of money laundering, customer due diligence (CDD), Know Your Customer (KYC), monitoring of politically exposed persons, and international cooperation.

name: UN Conventions on AML/CFT
description: Includes the UN Convention Against Illicit Traffic in Narcotic Drugs (1988), the UN Convention Against Transnational Organized Crime (2000), and the International Convention for the Suppression of the Financing of Terrorism (1999). These treaties require member states to criminalize money laundering and terrorism financing and underpin national AML/CFT laws.

name: Basel Committee on Banking Supervision Guidelines
description: Basel Committee guidelines provide principles for AML compliance in the banking sector, notably through the Customer Due Diligence for Banks paper. These are widely adopted by prudential regulators to assess financial institutions’ AML controls.

name: Egmont Group
description: An international network of Financial Intelligence Units (FIUs) aimed at enhancing cooperation and sharing of financial intelligence among member jurisdictions to combat money laundering and terrorist financing.

name: Bank Secrecy Act (BSA)
description: The primary U.S. AML law (1970). Requires financial institutions to establish AML programs, maintain records, and report certain financial transactions. Key reports include Currency Transaction Reports (CTRs) for cash ≥ $10,000 and Suspicious Activity Reports (SARs) for unusual activity.

name: USA PATRIOT Act
description: Expanded the BSA after 9/11 to combat terrorist financing. Requires customer identification programs (CIP), KYC processes, and screening clients against government watchlists. Prohibits accounts with foreign shell banks and encourages information sharing.

name: Anti-Money Laundering Act of 2020 (AMLA)
description: Part of the NDAA 2021, this law modernized U.S. AML frameworks. Introduced beneficial ownership reporting via the Corporate Transparency Act, strengthened penalties, expanded FinCEN’s powers, and created stronger whistleblower protections.

name: FinCEN and OFAC Regulations
description: FinCEN enforces AML rules under the BSA (e.g. the 2016 CDD Rule defining 'Beneficial Owner'). OFAC administers and enforces U.S. economic sanctions, requiring financial institutions to include sanctions screening in AML programs.

name: Industry-Specific AML Requirements
description: U.S. AML rules apply across various sectors: banks, MSBs, casinos, brokers, insurers, fintechs, and crypto firms. These entities must implement AML programs tailored to their risk profile and comply with additional regulations such as Geographic Targeting Orders.

name: EU Anti-Money Laundering Directives (AMLDs)
description: A series of directives harmonizing AML/CFT laws across EU member states. 4th AMLD (2015) introduced risk-based AML, gambling sector coverage, and UBO registries. 5th AMLD (2018) expanded scope to virtual currencies, prepaid cards, and required public UBO access. 6th AMLD (2021) defined 22 predicate offenses and introduced criminal liability for legal persons.

name: EU AML Regulations and AML Authority (AMLA)
description: The EU is shifting to a single AML rulebook and establishing a new AML Authority (AMLA) to directly supervise high-risk entities. Also includes obligations under the Funds Transfer Regulation, which enforces FATF's Travel Rule for originator/beneficiary information.

name: Member State AML Laws (e.g. Germany’s GwG, France’s CMF)
description: Each EU member state transposes AMLDs into national legislation (e.g., Germany’s Geldwäschegesetz, France’s Code Monétaire et Financier). These laws implement and enforce the harmonized EU AML framework under the oversight of national FIUs and supervisors.

name: Proceeds of Crime Act 2002 (POCA)
description: Core UK legislation criminalizing money laundering, including offenses such as concealing, arranging, acquiring/using criminal property, and failing to report or tipping off. It also enables asset confiscation and underpins the Suspicious Activity Reports (SARs) regime.

name: Money Laundering, Terrorist Financing and Transfer of Funds (Information) Regulations 2017
description: UK's transposition of the EU AML Directives, retained post-Brexit and updated in line with 5AMLD. Requires regulated entities to conduct customer due diligence, maintain records, and report suspicious activity. Covers cryptoasset businesses and requires beneficial ownership disclosures.

name: Terrorism Act 2000
description: Criminalizes the financing of terrorism and mandates reporting of knowledge or suspicion of terrorist financing. Supports the SAR regime for terror financing alongside POCA.

name: UK AML Supervisors and JMLIT
description: UK’s AML oversight is provided by multiple supervisors (e.g., FCA, HMRC, Gambling Commission), with public-private collaboration facilitated by the Joint Money Laundering Intelligence Taskforce (JMLIT). Post-Brexit reforms include stronger UBO verification and potential 'failure to prevent' offenses.

name: Proceeds of Crime (Money Laundering) and Terrorist Financing Act (PCMLTFA)
description: Canada’s main AML/CFT legislation. It applies to a wide range of reporting entities, such as banks, money services businesses, casinos, and real estate firms. It mandates client identification, recordkeeping, large and suspicious transaction reporting, and anti-terrorist financing obligations.

name: FINTRAC Regulations
description: Regulatory rules under the PCMLTFA enforced by FINTRAC, Canada’s Financial Intelligence Unit. These regulations detail requirements around KYC, ongoing monitoring, and the submission of Suspicious Transaction Reports (STRs) within 30 days of detection.

name: Criminal Code (Canada)
description: Criminalizes money laundering and terrorist financing. It also enforces compliance with financial sanctions under other statutes such as the United Nations Act and the Special Economic Measures Act, which require screening against lists of designated individuals and entities.

name: Provincial Initiatives on AML
description: Provincial governments have introduced additional anti-money laundering measures, especially in the real estate sector. For example, British Columbia has established a beneficial ownership property registry, and Ontario has rules requiring property owners to disclose true ownership.

name: Criminal Law of China (AML Provisions)
description: Criminalizes money laundering under China's Criminal Law. AML regulations issued by the People’s Bank of China require banks to verify customer identity, monitor transactions, and report large or suspicious activities to the China AML Monitoring and Analysis Center.

name: Anti-Money Laundering and Counter-Terrorist Financing Ordinance (AMLO)
description: Hong Kong's core AML/CFT law covering banks, securities firms, and casinos. Requires customer due diligence, recordkeeping, and suspicious transaction reporting. Supervised by HKMA, SFC, and Insurance Authority.

name: Corruption, Drug Trafficking and Other Serious Crimes (Confiscation of Benefits) Act (CDSA)
description: Singapore law criminalizing money laundering. Supported by MAS Notice 626 (for banks) and other notices for financial sectors requiring KYC, monitoring, screening, and STR filing. Payment Services Act (2019) extends AML obligations to fintech and crypto providers.

name: Act on Prevention of Transfer of Criminal Proceeds
description: Japan's main AML law requiring identity verification and reporting of suspicious transactions. Updated to cover virtual currency exchanges. Reports go to Japan’s Financial Intelligence Unit.

name: Prevention of Money Laundering Act (PMLA) 2002
description: India’s central AML legislation. Imposes obligations on banks and financial intermediaries to submit CTRs and STRs. Regulated via RBI’s KYC Master Directions. Crypto exchanges were added as reporting entities in 2023.

name: Anti-Money Laundering and Counter-Terrorism Financing Act 2006
description: Australia’s AML/CFT framework requiring entities to register with AUSTRAC, conduct KYC, and report large or suspicious transactions. Ongoing reforms aim to expand coverage to lawyers and real estate agents.

name: Various National AML Laws (South Korea, Malaysia, Indonesia, Thailand)
description: Countries across Asia-Pacific have AML laws aligned with FATF standards. These require customer due diligence, suspicious transaction reporting, and include provisions to regulate cryptoassets. Many have national FIUs to enforce compliance.

name: United Nations Convention against Corruption (UNCAC)
description: A 2003 UN treaty ratified by around 189 countries. It requires criminalization of domestic and foreign bribery, embezzlement, and money laundering. Also mandates preventive measures, asset recovery mechanisms, and international cooperation.

name: OECD Convention on Combating Bribery of Foreign Public Officials
description: A 1997 legally binding treaty requiring 44 signatory countries to criminalize bribery of foreign public officials in international business. Includes provisions for accurate recordkeeping to prevent off-book bribery and has influenced national laws like the UK Bribery Act and U.S. FCPA amendments.

name: OECD Guidelines for Multinational Enterprises
description: Voluntary corporate responsibility standards urging multinational companies to avoid bribery and adopt internal compliance programs. Updated in 2011 with anti-bribery provisions, widely used in CSR frameworks.

name: Inter-American Convention Against Corruption
description: 1996 regional treaty for OAS members, requiring signatories to adopt laws criminalizing bribery and implement preventive measures. Supports regional cooperation on corruption cases.

name: African Union Convention on Preventing and Combating Corruption
description: 2003 AU treaty promoting national anti-bribery laws, codes of conduct, and institutional reforms across African nations. Focuses on domestic and public sector corruption and regional cooperation.

name: ISO 37001 Anti-Bribery Management Systems
description: An international standard (2016) for organizations to establish anti-bribery compliance programs, covering risk assessment, training, monitoring, due diligence, and whistleblower protections.

name: Transparency International Anti-Corruption Frameworks
description: Transparency International provides globally recognized guidance, indices, and frameworks for governments and organizations to assess and combat corruption, including benchmarking tools and integrity system diagnostics.

name: Foreign Corrupt Practices Act (FCPA)
description: The FCPA (1977, amended in 1998) prohibits bribing foreign government officials to obtain or retain business. It includes anti-bribery provisions and accounting provisions requiring accurate books and internal controls to prevent bribery. Enforced by DOJ (criminal) and SEC (civil), with heavy fines and potential jail time. It has extraterritorial reach, applying to U.S. companies, citizens, foreign companies listed in the U.S., and foreign persons acting within U.S. jurisdiction.

name: Travel Act
description: The Travel Act (1961) allows prosecutors to charge bribery involving interstate commerce (including commercial bribery) as a federal crime. Often invoked in conjunction with state law violations, particularly in private-sector or domestic bribery cases.

name: Anti-Kickback Statutes
description: The Medicare/Medicaid Anti-Kickback Statute criminalizes paying kickbacks to induce referrals or purchases in federal healthcare programs. These laws aim to prevent fraud and abuse in the healthcare system, particularly in federally funded programs.

name: State Commercial Bribery Laws
description: Most U.S. states have laws prohibiting commercial bribery, which involves offering bribes to private entities' agents or bribery of state or local public officials. These laws are enforced in conjunction with the FCPA, which primarily covers bribery of foreign officials.

name: UK Bribery Act 2010
description: The UK Bribery Act 2010 is a broad anti-corruption law that criminalizes bribing another person, being bribed, bribing foreign public officials, and the failure of a commercial organization to prevent bribery. The last offense means companies can be held liable if anyone associated with them (employee, agent, subsidiary) pays bribes on their behalf unless the company had adequate procedures in place to prevent bribery. The Act applies universally to any company or person with close ties to the UK, regardless of where the offense occurred. Penalties can include up to 10 years imprisonment and unlimited fines.

name: Proceeds of Crime Act 2002 & Money Laundering Regulations
description: These laws come into play as bribery can generate 'proceeds' that, if concealed, violate money laundering regulations. Companies must report knowledge or suspicion of bribery proceeds or risk committing a POCA offense. The regulations are part of the broader effort to combat financial crime and prevent the laundering of illicit funds.

name: UK Corporate Governance Code & Listing Rules
description: While not laws, the UK Corporate Governance Code and Listing Rules set out expectations for companies listed on the London Stock Exchange. Companies are expected to have robust internal controls, including anti-bribery measures, and to report on principal risks, with corruption being a major risk area. These guidelines are vital for corporate transparency and compliance with anti-bribery standards.

name: Sapin II Law (France, 2016)
description: France’s Sapin II Law mandates large companies to implement anti-corruption compliance programs. It also established the Agence Française Anticorruption to oversee compliance and enforcement. The law aims to enhance corporate transparency, prevent corruption, and hold companies accountable for bribery and corruption offenses.

name: Criminal Code (Germany)
description: Germany's Criminal Code includes sections on bribery, with penalties for offering, giving, and accepting bribes. A Corporate Liability Act is also under development, aiming to hold companies accountable for failing to prevent bribery through their organizational structures. This law aligns with Germany's commitment to international anti-corruption standards.

name: Legislative Decree 231 (Italy)
description: Italy’s Legislative Decree 231 requires companies to adopt organizational models to prevent crimes, including bribery and corruption. It holds companies accountable for criminal offenses committed by employees or executives, providing an incentive for businesses to ensure strong anti-corruption controls.

name: EU Anti-Corruption Directives
description: The EU has issued directives aimed at enhancing public procurement integrity, with specific measures to combat corruption in procurement processes. Additionally, an EU Anti-Corruption Report mechanism monitors member states' anti-corruption efforts. The EU has also introduced a directive on whistleblower protection (2019) to support those who report corruption and bribery.

name: Anti-Bribery Laws (Russia)
description: Russia has recently enhanced its anti-bribery laws, criminalizing both foreign official bribery and commercial bribery. It has introduced a corporate offense for companies failing to prevent bribery, with the potential for significant fines. These changes reflect Russia’s efforts to align with international anti-corruption standards.

name: Corruption of Foreign Public Officials Act (CFPOA)
description: Canada’s Corruption of Foreign Public Officials Act criminalizes the bribery of foreign public officials and the falsification of books to hide such bribery. It applies to Canadian citizens and companies anywhere in the world. The law was strengthened in 2013 and has seen increasing enforcement, with notable prosecutions for overseas bribery.

name: Criminal Code (Domestic Bribery)
description: The Canadian Criminal Code addresses offenses related to bribing public officials at the federal, provincial, and municipal levels, as well as frauds on the government and secret commissions (commercial bribery). The penalties for bribery of public officials can include imprisonment of up to 14 years.

name: Provincial Laws & Integrity Regime
description: Various provinces in Canada have established public sector integrity laws and codes of conduct. Additionally, Canada's Integrity Regime allows for the debarment of companies convicted of corruption offenses from receiving federal contracts, ensuring that companies maintain high standards of integrity in public sector dealings.

name: China Criminal Law
description: China's Criminal Law criminalizes giving and receiving bribes, including bribes to foreign officials (amended in 2011). The National Supervisory Commission oversees public sector corruption, and the Unfair Competition Law addresses commercial bribery. Although not a member of the OECD Convention, China cooperates with international anti-corruption standards under UNCAC.

name: Prevention of Corruption Act (India) 1988 (Amended 2018)
description: The Prevention of Corruption Act criminalizes bribery to public servants and, as of the 2018 amendment, makes offering bribes an offense as well. The 2018 amendment also introduced corporate liability, allowing penalties for companies if any associated person pays a bribe on the company’s behalf unless the company had adequate procedures in place. India does not yet have a specific foreign bribery law, but the PCA covers bribery of Indian public officials by anyone.

name: Japan Criminal Code & Unfair Competition Prevention Act
description: Japan's Criminal Code covers bribery of domestic public officials, while the Unfair Competition Prevention Act criminalizes bribery of foreign public officials by Japanese companies. The law has been in effect since 1998 and aligns with the OECD Convention. Enforcement has historically been limited, but it has been improving in recent years.

name: Singapore Prevention of Corruption Act (PCA)
description: The Prevention of Corruption Act (PCA) is a robust law in Singapore covering both public and private sector bribery. The law presumes guilt for public servants with unexplained wealth, and the Corrupt Practices Investigation Bureau (CPIB) actively enforces both domestic and foreign bribery offenses.

name: Australia Criminal Code Division 70
description: Australia's Criminal Code Division 70 criminalizes bribery of foreign public officials, in line with the OECD Convention. The law also covers domestic public bribery. Starting in 2024, Australia will introduce a new offense for corporations failing to prevent foreign bribery, along with a deferred prosecution agreement regime for companies.

name: Other APAC Anti-Bribery Laws
description: Many Asia-Pacific countries have anti-bribery laws aligned with UNCAC. Notable examples include Malaysia's MACC Act, Indonesia's Anti-Corruption Law, and South Korea's Improper Solicitation and Graft Act (which limits the value of gifts to public officials). Hong Kong's ICAC and New Zealand's Serious Fraud Office actively enforce anti-bribery measures in both public and private sectors.

name: Brazil Clean Company Act (Law 12,846/2013)
description: The Clean Company Act imposes civil and administrative liability on companies for bribery, both domestic and foreign. Companies can be fined up to 20% of gross revenue and are incentivized to have compliance programs to qualify for leniency. This law complements Brazil's Penal Code, which criminalizes bribery of local officials. Brazil has been a party to the OECD Convention since 2000 and has pursued several high-profile cases like Operation Car Wash.

name: Mexico General Law of Administrative Responsibilities (2016)
description: The General Law of Administrative Responsibilities, under Mexico’s National Anti-Corruption System, establishes corporate liability for bribery (both domestic and foreign) and other corrupt acts. Individuals can face criminal penalties under the Penal Code for bribery offenses.

name: Argentina Corporate Criminal Liability Law (2018)
description: Argentina's Corporate Criminal Liability Law criminalizes corruption offenses, including the bribery of domestic and foreign officials. Companies can receive mitigation credit if they have implemented compliance programs to prevent corruption.

name: Colombia, Chile, Peru Corporate Liability for Foreign Bribery
description: Colombia, Chile, and Peru have introduced corporate liability for foreign bribery in line with their OECD commitments. Chile updated its anti-bribery laws in 2018 (Law 21.121), and Peru in 2016 (Legislative Decree 1352) to cover foreign bribery offenses.

name: Overall Latin America Anti-Corruption Frameworks
description: Across Latin America, countries are strengthening anti-corruption frameworks in response to major scandals and international treaties. Many countries have also passed whistleblower protection laws and established specialized anti-corruption prosecutors to enhance enforcement.

name: FATF Recommendations 24 & 25
description: FATF requires countries to ensure that competent authorities have access to accurate beneficial ownership information for companies (Recommendation 24) and trusts/legal arrangements (Recommendation 25). In 2022, FATF strengthened these standards, urging the creation of central registries or other mechanisms to obtain UBO information, thus driving national laws on corporate transparency.

name: G20 High-Level Principles on Beneficial Ownership Transparency (2014)
description: A commitment by G20 leaders to adopt measures for the transparency of companies and legal arrangements, inspired by FATF guidelines. These principles emphasize the need for beneficial ownership disclosure to prevent financial crimes like money laundering and corruption.

name: OECD Common Reporting Standard (CRS)
description: Primarily focused on tax information exchange, the OECD CRS also reveals the importance of knowing the true owners of bank accounts and legal entities. The CRS complements efforts to ensure corporate transparency and beneficial ownership disclosure.

name: Open Government Partnership & OpenOwnership
description: These multi-country initiatives promote public beneficial ownership registries. OpenOwnership’s Beneficial Ownership Data Standard provides a framework for publishing beneficial ownership data in a standardized, accessible format, aiding transparency efforts.

name: UN Convention Against Corruption (UNCAC)
description: The UN Convention Against Corruption encourages states to prevent the misuse of corporate entities for corruption, including through transparency about the identity of owners. While it doesn't explicitly require beneficial ownership registers, it forms part of broader preventive measures.

name: Corporate Transparency Act (CTA) 2020
description: A landmark U.S. law enacted as part of the Anti-Money Laundering Act (AMLA) of 2020, which requires most corporations, LLCs, and similar entities to file beneficial ownership information with the Financial Crimes Enforcement Network (FinCEN) starting January 1, 2024. A 'beneficial owner' is defined as an individual who substantially controls the entity or owns 25% or more. The law aims to address the gap in the U.S. AML framework and bring the U.S. in line with global beneficial ownership transparency standards.

name: Customer Due Diligence (CDD) Rule
description: A FinCEN regulation (2018) that requires banks to identify the beneficial owners of legal entity customers when opening accounts. Specifically, banks must identify owners holding 25% or more of the entity and a person with control over the entity. The CTA builds on this rule by centralizing beneficial ownership information at the incorporation stage, complementing banks' due diligence obligations.

name: SEC Requirements
description: Publicly listed companies in the U.S. must disclose major shareholders (owning 5% or more) and any changes in their holdings through 13D/G filings. While not directly focused on illicit activity, this regulation promotes transparency of corporate control and shareholder structure, especially in capital markets.

name: State Laws
description: While states handle incorporation, historically, they did not require beneficial ownership disclosure. Some states, like New York, have implemented their own disclosure requirements for certain transactions (e.g., LLC members in property purchases). The CTA creates a uniform federal standard for beneficial ownership disclosure, ensuring consistency across states.

name: EU Anti-Money Laundering Directives (4AMLD, 5AMLD)
description: The EU's Anti-Money Laundering Directives (4AMLD and 5AMLD) require member states to establish central registers of beneficial owners for companies and trusts. Under 4AMLD (2015), these registers were initially accessible to authorities and those with a 'legitimate interest.' 5AMLD (2018) broadened this access by making company UBO registers public, with optional registration for access. However, a 2022 EU Court of Justice ruling invalidated full public access, limiting it to those with legitimate interest. Despite this, companies are still required to file their UBO information (usually any owner or controlling person with >25%) with a government registry, which must be kept up-to-date.

name: Significant Shareholder Disclosures
description: The EU’s Transparency Directive requires listed companies' investors to disclose holdings above certain thresholds (e.g., 5%, 10%, etc.) to the market. This regulation, separate from AML registers, also contributes to promoting transparency in ownership and shareholder structures, supporting broader corporate transparency efforts in the EU.

name: Proposed EU AML Regulation
description: The proposed EU AML Regulation aims to standardize beneficial ownership rules across EU member states. This could include lowering the thresholds for ownership disclosures and enhancing the interconnectivity of UBO registers to ensure more effective cross-border collaboration and transparency.

name: European Beneficial Ownership Registers
description: Many EU member states have established beneficial ownership registers for companies, with countries like Denmark, France, and the Netherlands having fully public UBO registries before the 2022 EU Court of Justice ruling. While full public access to these registers has been restricted, authorities can still easily access UBO information. These registers help ensure that beneficial ownership information is publicly available, promoting corporate transparency within the EU.

name: People with Significant Control (PSC) Register
description: Since 2016, UK companies (and LLPs) must report individuals who ultimately own or control more than 25% of shares or voting rights, or otherwise exercise significant control. This PSC information is publicly available via Companies House. The UK was a pioneer with a public beneficial ownership register. Upcoming reforms (via the Economic Crime and Corporate Transparency Bill) will strengthen verification of identities on the register.

name: Register of Overseas Entities (ROE)
description: Introduced in 2022, this requires overseas companies that own UK real estate to disclose their beneficial owners to Companies House. This measure was aimed at curbing dirty money in UK property. As of early 2023, many entities failed to meet the reporting deadline, and enforcement is underway.

name: Trust Registration Service (TRS)
description: UK trusts (and some foreign trusts with UK assets) must register their beneficial owners (settlors, trustees, beneficiaries) with the HMRC Trust Register. While the register is not public, it is accessible to law enforcement and those with legitimate interest, supporting efforts to improve transparency in trust ownership.

name: Significant Shareholder Notifications
description: Under UK Listing Rules, listed firms are required to announce shareholders crossing 3% ownership thresholds. While not directly an anti-money laundering measure, this regulation complements corporate transparency by promoting shareholder disclosure in publicly traded companies.

name: Provincial Corporate Transparency
description: Canada is moving toward beneficial ownership (BO) registers, but currently the system is fragmented. For instance, British Columbia and Quebec have established provincial beneficial owner registries for corporations. Ontario and other provinces are planning or have implemented partial measures.

name: Federal Beneficial Ownership Registry
description: The Canadian federal government has committed to establishing a public beneficial ownership registry for federally incorporated companies by 2025. Legislation is currently in progress to support this initiative.

name: PCMLTFA (Proceeds of Crime (Money Laundering) and Terrorist Financing Act)
description: Under PCMLTFA, financial institutions are required to collect beneficial ownership information for clients that are entities. Although there wasn’t a central repository before, recent amendments have strengthened the verification and recording requirements for beneficial owners.

name: Securities Law (Investor Disclosure)
description: In line with U.S. practices, Canadian securities law mandates that investors acquiring 10% or more of a public company’s shares must publicly report their ownership. An early warning system is in place for acquisitions of 5% or more, promoting transparency of large shareholdings.

name: Singapore Register of Controllers
description: Since 2017, Singapore requires companies to maintain a Register of Controllers, listing individuals or legal entities with significant interest or control, generally those with more than 25% ownership or control. This register is not public but must be provided to the government upon request. Similarly, Singapore trusts must keep records of beneficial owners.

name: Hong Kong Significant Controllers Register
description: Implemented in 2018, the Significant Controllers Register requires companies to identify and record individuals or entities with more than 25% of shares/votes or significant influence. The register is accessible to law enforcement.

name: Australia Shareholder Disclosure & UBO Transparency
description: Australia does not yet have a public beneficial ownership register for companies but has robust shareholder disclosure requirements for listed companies. Additionally, there are ongoing discussions and reviews for improving transparency for trusts and partnerships.

name: Offshore Financial Centers (Cayman, BVI, etc.) BO Registers
description: In response to international pressure, many offshore financial centers, such as the Cayman Islands and British Virgin Islands, have introduced private beneficial ownership registers. These registers are accessible to authorities via information exchange mechanisms. For instance, the Cayman Islands now requires companies to file BO information with a competent authority, though it remains private unless a UK order comes into effect.

name: Global Trend of BO Transparency Reforms
description: Over 100 jurisdictions worldwide have committed to implementing beneficial ownership transparency reforms. Examples include Ukraine’s public UBO register, Dubai’s (UAE) 2020 regulations requiring companies to report UBOs, and Nigeria’s 2020 Companies and Allied Matters Act mandating BO disclosures. These reforms align with the FATF’s efforts to combat anonymous shell companies.

name: United Nations Security Council Sanctions
description: Binding on all UN member states, the UNSC can impose sanctions through resolutions under Chapter VII of the UN Charter. Sanctions include asset freezes, travel bans, and arms embargoes against certain individuals, entities, or countries (e.g., North Korea, Iran, ISIS/Al-Qaida). These sanctions are enforced domestically by UN member states, and businesses are required to comply, including freezing assets of listed persons.

name: European Union Sanctions
description: The EU enacts all UN sanctions and also implements its own autonomous sanctions (e.g., asset freezes and embargoes against countries or entities like Russia, Syria, terrorism lists). EU persons and companies must comply directly with these regulations. The EU Consolidated Financial Sanctions list is maintained by the European Commission, with the UK post-Brexit maintaining a similar regime.

name: Office of Foreign Assets Control (OFAC) Sanctions
description: The U.S. Treasury Department’s OFAC administers multiple sanctions programs, including country-based programs (Cuba, Iran) and list-based programs (e.g., counter-terrorism, narcotics trafficking, cyber sanctions). The primary list is the Specially Designated Nationals (SDN) List, which includes individuals, companies, and even cryptocurrency addresses under sanction. U.S. persons are prohibited from transacting with SDNs, and non-U.S. companies can face secondary sanctions for certain dealings.

name: Canada Sanctions
description: Canada has its own sanctions lists, which largely align with the UN, U.S., and EU sanctions, under the Special Economic Measures Act and the United Nations Act. Canadian entities must comply with these lists.

name: Australia, Japan, Switzerland Sanctions
description: Australia, Japan, and Switzerland maintain their own sanctions regimes, often in alignment with the UN, EU, and U.S. sanctions. These countries impose asset freezes, trade embargoes, and other restrictions.

name: China Counter-Sanctions Law
description: In response to foreign sanctions, China introduced a counter-sanctions law and an ‘unreliable entities list’ in 2021, and a new anti-espionage law in 2023. These laws require Chinese companies to be cautious not to comply with foreign sanctions in ways that could trigger China's countermeasures.

name: Global Magnitsky and Human Rights Sanctions
description: The U.S., Canada, UK, and EU have regimes to sanction individuals involved in human rights violations or grand corruption, similar to the Global Magnitsky Act. These sanctions typically involve asset freezes and travel bans.

name: FATF Recommendation 12
description: FATF Recommendation 12 requires financial institutions to identify customers or beneficial owners who are Politically Exposed Persons (PEPs), including foreign PEPs such as senior officials, heads of state, judges, military leaders, and their immediate family and close associates. Institutions must apply enhanced due diligence (EDD), obtain senior management approval, establish the source of wealth/funds, and monitor the account closely.

name: EU AML Directives (4AMLD)
description: The EU Anti-Money Laundering Directives, particularly the 4AMLD, incorporated FATF's PEP requirements into law. EU firms must screen customers against known PEP lists and apply enhanced due diligence (EDD) for foreign PEPs. Domestic PEPs are also subject to specific measures under this directive.

name: U.S. Regulation (BSA/Patriot Act)
description: Under the U.S. Bank Secrecy Act (BSA) and the Patriot Act, U.S. financial institutions are expected to have risk-based procedures for PEPs, although the term 'PEP' isn’t explicitly in statute. The regulations require enhanced due diligence (EDD) for private banking accounts of non-U.S. persons with senior political positions (Section 312 of the Patriot Act). U.S. banks also treat domestic senior politicians as higher-risk.

name: PEP Lists
description: Commercial databases compile global PEP lists, such as those from World-Check, Dow Jones, and Factiva. These databases are used by financial institutions to flag new account holders who are PEPs. While there is no single global public PEP list, some countries publish domestic PEP roles. Compliance programs use these lists to enhance monitoring and detect potential corruption.

name: Sanctions Overlap
description: Sometimes, PEPs are also subject to sanctions, such as when an individual minister is on the OFAC Specially Designated Nationals (SDN) list for corruption. Screening tools often check both PEP status and sanctions lists to ensure compliance with both sets of regulations.

name: Transaction and Customer Screening
description: Financial institutions and many companies are required to screen customer databases and transactions against sanctions lists (e.g., UN, OFAC, EU) in real-time or daily. If a match is found, the institution must freeze assets and report to authorities (e.g., OFAC blocking report or EU asset freeze notification). Sanctions screening is mandated by most jurisdictions' AML/CFT laws.

name: Watchlists and Tools
description: Institutions screen against multiple sanctions lists beyond the SDN list, including the BIS Denied Persons List for export violations, U.S. State Department Nonproliferation sanctions, and other countries' lists. Automated software is commonly used to flag potential matches, with manual review necessary to resolve false positives.

name: FATF High-Risk Jurisdictions Lists
description: FATF identifies countries with weak AML/CFT regimes via the 'Black List' and 'Gray List'. Financial institutions are required to apply enhanced due diligence (EDD) when doing business involving these jurisdictions. Regulators may further restrict dealings with blacklisted countries (e.g., North Korea, Iran). The EU also maintains a list of high-risk third countries triggering enhanced checks by EU banks.

name: Proliferation Financing and Export Controls
description: UN Security Council sanctions lists include countries like North Korea and Iran for WMD proliferation. FATF Rec.7 requires screening for proliferation financing as well. Many countries require screening of trade transactions for proliferation red flags and to ensure that sanctioned parties are not involved.

name: Ongoing Monitoring
description: Sanctions lists are frequently updated, and firms must have procedures in place to update list data and rescreen existing customers periodically. Ongoing transaction monitoring is essential to detect potential indirect sanctions evasion (e.g., payments involving third parties controlled by sanctioned entities).

name: Penalties
description: Violating sanctions regulations can lead to significant penalties, including heavy fines and criminal charges. Global banks have faced billions of dollars in fines for sanctions breaches, often related to processing payments for sanctioned countries or entities. Sanctions compliance is one of the most strictly enforced aspects of corporate compliance.

name: Wassenaar Arrangement
description: A 42-nation arrangement coordinating export controls on conventional arms and dual-use goods & technologies. Participating countries (US, EU states, Russia, Japan, etc.) maintain national control lists based on Wassenaar’s agreed lists (munitions list and dual-use list). While not legally binding internationally, members implement its guidelines in their laws, ensuring global consistency.

name: Missile Technology Control Regime (MTCR), Nuclear Suppliers Group (NSG), Australia Group (Chemical/Bio weapons)
description: Multilateral regimes focused on controlling the export of items related to missiles, nuclear, and chemical/biological weapons. These regimes shape national export control lists and license policies, ensuring coordinated global compliance on sensitive items.

name: Arms Trade Treaty (ATT)
description: A 2014 UN treaty regulating the international trade in conventional arms. Requires states to assess exports to ensure they won’t be used for genocide, terrorism, or other prohibited activities. Major exporters like the US, Russia, and China are not parties, but many other nations are signatories.

name: World Trade Organization (WTO) Rules
description: The WTO prohibits quantitative restrictions on trade but allows exceptions for security (GATT Article XXI) and other reasons. WTO norms encourage free trade and non-discrimination, meaning export controls should be justified and targeted. Export controls must comply with WTO obligations or claim exceptions for security and other reasons.

name: Free Trade Agreements (FTAs)
description: Free Trade Agreements (e.g., USMCA, EU trade agreements, CPTPP, RCEP) often contain clauses on customs cooperation, trade facilitation, and data transfer. Compliance means utilizing trade agreement benefits legally and adhering to prohibited practices such as unwarranted data localization or customs duties on electronic transmissions.

name: Export Administration Regulations (EAR)
description: Administered by the Bureau of Industry and Security (BIS) under the U.S. Department of Commerce. Controls 'dual-use' items (commercial items with potential military use) and sensitive military items. The EAR includes the Commerce Control List (CCL), which specifies export licensing requirements based on destination, end user, and end use. Companies must screen transactions for restricted end-uses (e.g., WMD proliferation) and denied parties (BIS maintains separate lists like the Entity List and Denied Persons List). Violations can lead to penalties and denial of export privileges.

name: International Traffic in Arms Regulations (ITAR)
description: Administered by the U.S. Department of State’s Directorate of Defense Trade Controls (DDTC). ITAR controls the export of defense articles and services listed on the U.S. Munitions List (USML). It requires licensing for the export of military goods, technology, and services, including re-export and retransfer controls. ITAR also prohibits exports to certain countries and individuals, and has extraterritorial reach, meaning non-U.S. entities must comply if handling ITAR-controlled items. Violations can lead to severe fines and criminal charges.

name: Anti-Boycott Regulations
description: Under the EAR, U.S. companies are prohibited from participating in unsanctioned foreign boycotts, particularly the Arab League boycott of Israel. Companies must report any boycott requests they receive. This aspect of trade compliance is particularly relevant for companies doing business in the Middle East.

name: Customs and Import Regulations
description: Enforced by U.S. Customs and Border Protection (CBP). These regulations govern the proper classification, valuation, and country-of-origin marking of goods. Companies must ensure they do not import prohibited goods (e.g., products made with forced labor). Section 307 of the Tariff Act bans such imports, with enforcement via Withhold Release Orders. Companies must also comply with trade remedy measures like antidumping and countervailing duties, and preferential tariff rules under agreements like USMCA.

name: Sectoral Export Controls
description: Certain industries have additional controls, such as the export of nuclear technology under the U.S. Department of Energy (DOE) and Nuclear Regulatory Commission (NRC) regulations (e.g., 10 CFR Part 810, Part 110), and defense services regulated under ITAR Technical Assistance Agreements.

name: EU Dual-Use Regulation (Regulation (EU) 2021/821)
description: Controls the export, transfer, brokering, and transit of dual-use items from the EU. It lists controlled items, which are aligned with multilateral regimes like Wassenaar and MTCR. Requires licenses for sensitive destinations or end uses. Introduced 'human security' controls, particularly for cyber-surveillance technology. Licenses are issued by individual member states under a common EU framework, with some general authorizations for less sensitive exports.

name: EU Military Items Control (Common Position 2008/944/CFSP)
description: Controls arms exports from EU member states under national laws, guided by the Common Position 2008/944/CFSP. Sets criteria such as human rights, regional stability, and risk of diversion to unauthorized end users to evaluate export licenses for military goods. Many EU countries publish annual reports on arms exports.

name: Brexit & UK Strategic Export Control Lists
description: Following Brexit, the UK now operates under its own Export Control Order 2008 (updated), with strategic export control lists mirroring EU lists. The UK requires licenses similar to the EU system, but with the ability to diverge in sanctions and arms embargoes. Despite this, the UK remains aligned with the EU/US on key issues like sanctions against Russia.

name: Japan Export Controls (Foreign Exchange and Foreign Trade Act)
description: Japan's export controls are governed by the Foreign Exchange and Foreign Trade Act, aligning with multilateral export control regimes and often introducing additional restrictions. Japanese companies are known for strict compliance with these regulations, with heavy penalties and potential loss of export privileges for violations, particularly regarding sensitive technologies and military goods.

name: Canada Export and Import Permits Act
description: Canada's export controls are governed by the Export and Import Permits Act, which includes an export control list and area control list. These lists impose strict controls on exports to countries like North Korea. Violations can lead to severe penalties, including export privilege revocation.

name: Australia Customs Act and Defense Trade Controls Act
description: Australia controls exports through the Customs Act and the Defense Trade Controls Act. These laws control not only goods but also services and the publication of sensitive technical information. The regulations ensure compliance with both domestic and international trade and national security standards.

name: India SCOMET List (Special Chemicals, Organisms, Materials, Equipment, and Technologies)
description: India controls the export of dual-use goods under the SCOMET list as part of its Foreign Trade Policy. A license is required for the export of items listed on the SCOMET list, which covers a range of sensitive goods and technologies, including those related to chemicals, biological agents, and military applications.

name: China Export Control Law (2020)
description: China's Export Control Law (2020) provides a unified framework for controlling the export of sensitive goods and technologies, including military and dual-use items. It includes provisions for national security concerns and allows for reciprocal actions based on international trade relations. China also has a list of controlled items and can prohibit exports if they pose a risk to national security.

name: GDPR Data Transfer Restrictions
description: The GDPR (General Data Protection Regulation) Chapter V prohibits the transfer of personal data outside the European Economic Area (EEA) to countries lacking adequate data protection, unless an exception or safeguard is in place. Adequacy decisions (e.g., for Japan, Switzerland, UK, Israel, Canada commercial sector, etc.) allow free flow of data. Otherwise, Standard Contractual Clauses (SCCs), Binding Corporate Rules, or other approved mechanisms must be used. Schrems II (2020) invalidated the EU–US Privacy Shield, leading to SCCs being the main tool for transfers until the EU-US Data Privacy Framework in 2023.

name: Critical Data/Cloud (EU Cybersecurity Certification - EUCS)
description: The EU proposed the Cybersecurity Certification (EUCS) that could include local presence requirements for cloud providers serving critical sectors. While not strict localization, the proposal aims to ensure that certain services like cloud storage for critical data have a sufficient presence within the EU. Additionally, sector-specific regulations (e.g., financial services) may require certain data to be accessible within the EU for regulatory supervision.

name: Member State Laws on Localization
description: Some EU member states have specific sectorial data localization requirements, such as Germany's telecom metadata retention laws and France's mandates for the local storage of health data. These regulations were often challenged under EU single market laws but reflect national concerns about sovereignty and security. Many such rules have been adjusted to conform with broader EU regulations while addressing localized needs.

name: Defense: ITAR-Controlled Data
description: Under the International Traffic in Arms Regulations (ITAR), certain technical data must not be disclosed to foreign persons unless authorized. This effectively requires that ITAR-controlled data be stored or accessed only by U.S. persons within the U.S., or through the use of specific licenses or U.S.-based infrastructure (e.g., FedRAMP High cloud services).

name: Government Data Storage (FedRAMP)
description: Certain U.S. federal agencies mandate that government data be stored domestically or within certified cloud environments, such as those approved under FedRAMP (Federal Risk and Authorization Management Program). This ensures sensitive data is handled securely within designated parameters, often requiring U.S.-based data centers and personnel.

name: Healthcare Data (HIPAA and State Laws)
description: While the Health Insurance Portability and Accountability Act (HIPAA) does not explicitly require data localization, it mandates the safeguarding of health records. Some state-level laws, such as Texas HB 300, require that health records remain accessible within the state, which can affect how healthcare data is stored and managed across jurisdictions.

name: Tax Records (IRS Requirements)
description: The Internal Revenue Service (IRS) requires certain tax-related records to be available in the U.S. upon request, but there is no strict prohibition on storing these records abroad. The records must be accessible for auditing and tax purposes as part of compliance with U.S. tax laws.

name: Cloud Act (2018)
description: The Clarifying Lawful Overseas Use of Data Act (Cloud Act) clarifies that U.S. law enforcement can subpoena data stored overseas if it is held by a U.S. service provider. The Cloud Act also establishes a framework for bilateral agreements between the U.S. and other countries to facilitate law enforcement access to data, effectively extending U.S. jurisdictional reach to data stored abroad.

name: Anti-Localization Stance (WTO and Trade Agreements)
description: The U.S. opposes forced data localization in international trade negotiations, arguing that it restricts business and cybersecurity. U.S. trade agreements, such as the USMCA, prevent other countries from requiring data to be stored locally, provided that regulators have prompt access to the data (with some exceptions for specific industries like financial services). USMCA Article 19.12 is an example of this stance.

name: China - Personal Information Protection Law (PIPL)
description: The Personal Information Protection Law (PIPL) mandates that critical infrastructure operators and large data processors store personal data within China or undergo a security assessment before exporting it. Standard Contract Clauses or certifications can be used for less sensitive data exports, but multinational firms often need to localize Chinese customer data or obtain government clearance for transfers.

name: China - Data Security Law (DSL)
description: The Data Security Law requires important data, which affects national security, economic development, and public interest, to be stored within China. Exporting this data requires approval. The definition of 'important data' varies by sector, adding complexity to compliance.

name: China - Cybersecurity Law (2017)
description: The 2017 Cybersecurity Law initiated restrictions on the transfer of critical information by operators of critical information infrastructure (CII). These operators are required to store data within China and undergo security assessments for certain data exports.

name: Russia - Personal Data Law (2015)
description: Since 2015, Russia's Personal Data Law requires personal data of Russian citizens to be stored in Russia. While data transfers are allowed, the primary copy must remain in Russia, often requiring local storage and mirroring. Non-compliance has led to fines and service bans (e.g., LinkedIn).

name: India - Data Protection Bill (DPDP Act 2023)
description: The DPDP Act 2023 allows data transfers to whitelisted countries, moving away from strict localization requirements. However, India's financial sector has mandated transaction data storage within the country, impacting companies like Visa and MasterCard. Other sectors may see similar rules in future policies.

name: India - RBI Payment Data Localization
description: The Reserve Bank of India (RBI) directed payment companies (Visa, MasterCard, etc.) to store transaction data within India. This regulation is part of India's broader push to retain control over sensitive financial data and ensure local accessibility.

name: Indonesia - Data Localization (2019)
description: Indonesia's 2019 update eased previous data localization laws. Now, only specific sectors like public services and banking are required to localize data, while the private sector can transfer data as long as regulatory access and security measures are in place.

name: Vietnam - Cybersecurity Law (2018)
description: Vietnam's 2018 Cybersecurity Law requires foreign tech companies to store data on Vietnamese users within the country and establish a local presence. This applies to critical companies like social media, telecom, and e-commerce platforms, with a focus on personal data and user relationships.

name: South Korea - Data Transfers (APPI)
description: South Korea does not mandate localization for private data, but the Personal Information Protection Act (APPI) allows data transfers under consent or adequate safeguards. Only certain data, such as MyNumber identification info, requires local storage in South Korea.

name: Japan - APPI and Data Transfers
description: Japan's Act on the Protection of Personal Information (APPI) facilitates data transfers with consent or adequate safeguards. It does not mandate data localization, except for certain sensitive information like MyNumber identification, which must be stored within Japan.

name: Australia - Critical Infrastructure Act (2022)
description: Australia's 2022 Security of Critical Infrastructure Act could result in some localization requirements for industries deemed critical. This includes data residency requirements for sectors like energy, communications, and water, though no broad data localization law exists.

name: Middle East - Data Localization
description: Countries like Saudi Arabia and the UAE have introduced localization requirements for government and sometimes banking data. Multinational companies operating in these regions may face local copy requirements for data in various sectors.

name: Brazil - General Data Protection Law (LGPD)
description: Brazil's General Data Protection Law (LGPD) does not mandate data localization. Transfers of personal data are allowed if the destination country has adequate protection or if standard contractual clauses (SCCs) are used. Brazil's Data Protection Authority (DPA) is formulating these clauses.

name: Argentina - Data Protection Law
description: Argentina allows cross-border transfers of personal data if certain conditions are met, such as obtaining consent or ensuring adequate safeguards are in place. There is no broad mandate for data localization.

name: Chile - Data Protection Law (Draft Bill)
description: Chile's draft Data Protection Bill, as of 2025, proposes data exports only to countries that offer adequate protection, effectively adopting an EU-style approach. This would allow for transfers under specific conditions similar to GDPR's adequacy or consent mechanisms.

name: Colombia - Data Protection Law
description: Colombia allows cross-border data transfers under conditions such as obtaining consent from data subjects or ensuring adequate safeguards. No strict data localization requirements are in place.

name: Mexico - Accounting Data Localization
description: Mexico requires that original accounting records remain within the country for regulatory oversight, particularly in the financial sector. This is not a broad localization mandate for personal data, but a specific requirement for business data.

name: Latin America - Telecommunications and Financial Sectors
description: Some Latin American regulators, particularly in telecommunications and financial sectors, require that customer data be accessible within the country for regulatory purposes. However, full-scale data localization is uncommon across the region.

name: Cloud Providers & Localization
description: Companies using cloud services need to ensure that their cloud providers offer region-specific data centers to comply with data localization laws. The compliance questionnaire should check whether vendors know where they store data and if they can accommodate localization requirements (e.g. EU-only hosting for EU personal data, China hosting for China operations).

name: Cross-Border Transfer Mechanisms
description: Organizations must implement transfer mechanisms such as standard contractual clauses, intra-group agreements, or obtain consents for cross-border data transfers where necessary. After the Schrems II ruling, many companies perform Transfer Impact Assessments for EU to non-EU data flows to ensure compliance with GDPR and other privacy regulations.

name: Localization vs. Backup
description: Some data localization laws allow for data copies abroad if the primary data is stored in-country. For instance, Russia's law essentially requires data mirroring (keeping primary data locally and only necessary backups abroad). Compliance means designing data architecture that keeps required data in-country while handling only non-essential copies abroad.

name: Penalties for Non-Compliance
description: Non-compliance with data localization and cross-border transfer regulations can result in significant penalties. For example, Roskomnadzor in Russia can issue fines or block services, while China's CAC can impose heavy penalties or shut down services. Violating GDPR transfer rules can lead to fines of up to 4% of global turnover.

name: Data Sovereignty in Contracts
description: Many corporate and government RFPs now include clauses asking vendors whether data will remain within a specific country. Compliance-aware vendors should recognize these requirements and ensure they meet local data sovereignty laws, especially as part of the contracting process.

name: HIPAA (USA)
description: HIPAA regulates health data privacy and security. Covered entities such as hospitals, clinics, and insurers, as well as their business associates, must implement controls for protecting PHI (Protected Health Information). Compliance questionnaires for healthcare vendors often inquire about HIPAA training, policies, and whether the vendor will sign a Business Associate Agreement.

name: HITECH Act (USA)
description: The HITECH Act strengthens HIPAA by mandating breach notifications and extending certain provisions to business associates. It also incentivizes the use of electronic health records and sets compliance standards for their security.

name: 21 CFR Part 11 (USA FDA)
description: This regulation governs electronic records and signatures in the pharmaceutical and medical device sectors. It ensures that these records are trustworthy and equivalent to paper. Compliance requires validation, audit trails, and other security measures. Vendors providing software to pharma/medical device companies may need to comply with 21 CFR Part 11.

name: GDPR (EU) – Health Data
description: Under GDPR, health data is considered a 'special category' requiring stricter consent or other legal justifications for processing. EU member states may also have additional laws regulating patient data, such as France’s Health Data Hosting certification.

name: ICH GxP (International)
description: In the pharmaceutical industry, Good Clinical Practice (GCP), Good Laboratory Practice (GLP), and Good Manufacturing Practice (GMP) are critical standards that ensure the quality and integrity of clinical trials, laboratory work, and manufacturing. Vendors handling clinical trial data may be asked about compliance with 21 CFR 11 and GCP.

name: WHO Guidelines & National Healthcare Laws
description: Various national healthcare laws, along with the World Health Organization (WHO) guidelines, govern patient confidentiality, telemedicine, and other healthcare practices. For example, in Singapore, patient data handling must comply with the Personal Data Protection Act (PDPA) and Ministry of Health (MOH) guidelines.

name: Sarbanes-Oxley Act (SOX)
description: The Sarbanes-Oxley Act (SOX) is a federal law that regulates corporate governance and financial reporting integrity for public companies. Section 404 requires management and auditors to attest to the effectiveness of internal controls over financial reporting. SOX is often categorized under finance compliance as it focuses on accounting controls, and vendors managing financial systems may need to follow SOX controls or frameworks like COSO.

name: Gramm-Leach-Bliley Act (GLBA)
description: The Gramm-Leach-Bliley Act (GLBA) mandates financial institutions to establish a security program to protect customer data. Vendors working with banks are often required to comply with the GLBA Safeguards Rule, which ties into broader information security compliance, including frameworks like ISO and NIST.

name: Dodd-Frank Act & Consumer Finance
description: The Dodd-Frank Act, introduced after the 2008 financial crisis, created new compliance burdens for financial institutions, including the Volcker Rule (which limits proprietary trading) and CFPB regulations for consumer protection. Vendors in fintech or lending are often asked to comply with these regulations, such as ensuring that lending algorithms align with the Equal Credit Opportunity Act.

name: Basel III
description: Basel III is an international regulatory framework issued by the Basel Committee on capital adequacy, liquidity, and risk management for banks. It is implemented via national regulations (e.g., Federal Reserve rules in the U.S., Capital Requirements Regulation/Directive in the EU). Third-party vendors providing risk modeling may need to support Basel III compliance by calculating risk-weighted assets.

name: Solvency II
description: Solvency II is a regulatory framework for the insurance industry in the EU, focusing on capital requirements, risk management, and supervisory reporting for insurers. Vendors serving the insurance sector may need to comply with Solvency II standards for reporting and data handling.

name: MiFID II / MiFIR
description: The Markets in Financial Instruments Directive II (MiFID II) and the corresponding MiFIR Regulation overhaul trading practices in the EU. They require transparency in pre- and post-trade reporting, investor protection, and controls on algorithmic trading. Tech vendors providing trading systems may need to ensure compliance with MiFID II requirements such as trade timestamping.

name: EMIR & Dodd-Frank Title VII
description: The European Market Infrastructure Regulation (EMIR) and Dodd-Frank Title VII impose requirements on the central clearing, trade reporting, and risk mitigation of over-the-counter (OTC) derivatives. Financial vendors dealing with swaps or derivatives processing may be asked about compliance with these regulations.

name: Payment Card Industry Data Security Standard (PCI-DSS)
description: The Payment Card Industry Data Security Standard (PCI-DSS) is a set of requirements for any entity that stores, processes, or transmits credit card data. PCI-DSS enforces requirements such as maintaining firewalls, encrypting cardholder data, and regular testing. Compliance is enforced contractually through banks and card networks.

name: PSD2 & Open Banking
description: The Payment Services Directive 2 (PSD2) and Open Banking regulations in the EU require strong customer authentication for payments and mandate that banks open their APIs to third parties. Fintech vendors in the EU must comply with PSD2’s security and consent rules.

name: SWIFT CSP
description: The Society for Worldwide Interbank Financial Telecommunication (SWIFT) has a Customer Security Programme (CSP) that requires all member banks to implement controls to prevent cyber fraud in payments. Although not a law, it is effectively required for banks in the SWIFT network.

name: FERPA (Family Educational Rights and Privacy Act)
description: The Family Educational Rights and Privacy Act (FERPA) protects the privacy of student education records at schools receiving federal funds. Schools must have written permission to release records, and students or parents have the right to access and correct records. Educational technology (EdTech) vendors often sign contracts agreeing to FERPA safeguards.

name: COPPA (Children's Online Privacy Protection Act)
description: The Children's Online Privacy Protection Act (COPPA) applies to EdTech services targeting children under 13 years old (e.g., online learning platforms). It requires obtaining parental consent for the collection of personal information from children. COPPA safeguards are commonly included in contracts with EdTech vendors serving children.

name: GDPR (EU) & Education
description: The General Data Protection Regulation (GDPR) applies to educational institutions as data controllers in the EU. While there is no specific EU law like FERPA, GDPR includes provisions for the protection of children’s data, with an age-of-consent for information society services typically set between 13-16 years old depending on the country.

name: State Student Privacy Laws (USA)
description: Various U.S. states have passed additional student privacy laws, such as California's SOPIPA (Student Online Privacy Protection Act), which limits the use of student data by EdTech companies for purposes like advertising. Compliance questionnaires for educational SaaS platforms may inquire about adherence to these state-specific laws.

name: ISO 27018
description: ISO 27018 is a code of practice for protecting personal data in the cloud, particularly relevant for sectors like education handling personally identifiable information (PII). Though not specific to education, it is often adopted by EdTech providers to demonstrate privacy controls and safeguard student data in cloud environments.

name: FedRAMP (Federal Risk and Authorization Management Program)
description: The Federal Risk and Authorization Management Program (FedRAMP) is a framework that cloud services must meet to be used by U.S. federal agencies. It includes impact levels (Low, Moderate, High) based on NIST 800-53 controls. Vendors selling cloud services to U.S. agencies must obtain FedRAMP Authorization to ensure compliance with federal security standards.

name: NIST SP 800-171 / CMMC (Cybersecurity Maturity Model Certification)
description: NIST SP 800-171 outlines security requirements for protecting Controlled Unclassified Information (CUI) in non-federal systems. It’s required by DFARS clause for defense contractors handling CUI. The Department of Defense (DoD) is implementing the Cybersecurity Maturity Model Certification (CMMC), which certifies contractors based on their adherence to NIST 800-171 and other practices. Compliance is mandatory for defense vendors, making it a common topic in the defense supply chain.

name: ITAR & EAR (International Traffic in Arms Regulations & Export Administration Regulations)
description: The International Traffic in Arms Regulations (ITAR) and the Export Administration Regulations (EAR) govern the export of defense-related technologies and goods from the U.S. These regulations require compliance with technology control plans and personnel security clearances when handling sensitive defense data or products. Vendors in the defense sector must comply with these export control laws.

name: Government Contracting Compliance
description: U.S. government contracting regulations such as the False Claims Act, Procurement Integrity Act, and Anti-Kickback Act ensure that government contractors meet ethical standards and contractual obligations. These laws require contractors to refrain from misrepresenting contract requirements or engaging in illegal business practices. Compliance is often assessed in vendor questionnaires focused on ethics training for companies in the government supply chain.

name: National Security Reviews (e.g., CFIUS, NSI Act, FDI Screening)
description: National security reviews, such as the Committee on Foreign Investment in the United States (CFIUS) and similar frameworks like the UK's NSI Act and the EU's Foreign Direct Investment (FDI) screening, are designed to review foreign investments in sensitive technologies and industries. While these laws may not directly apply to vendors, they are important to consider in contexts involving sensitive technology or deals that may affect national security.

name: NERC CIP (Critical Infrastructure Protection)
description: The NERC CIP standards are designed to ensure the cybersecurity of North America's electric utilities, particularly focusing on the protection of the power grid. Vendors supplying to the energy sector may need to align with NERC CIP requirements to demonstrate their commitment to safeguarding critical infrastructure.

name: EPA Regulations & Environmental Compliance
description: Factories and other industrial facilities in the U.S. must comply with the Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) regulations, which require environmental permits and adherence to safety standards. Compliance may also extend to Environmental, Social, and Governance (ESG) considerations, such as REACH (EU chemical regulation) or RoHS (restriction of hazardous substances in electronics) in the manufacturing sector.

name: Industry-Specific ESG Standards
