description: The Equator Principles and the IFC Performance Standards are key ESG frameworks in the finance and project development sectors. They ensure social and environmental risk management in project finance, helping companies and financiers assess the sustainability and impact of projects.

name: ISO/IEC 27001
description: ISO/IEC 27001 is an international standard for Information Security Management Systems (ISMS). Organizations can become certified to demonstrate a systematic approach to securing data, including risk assessments, controls, and incident response. Related standards include ISO 27017 (cloud security), ISO 27018 (privacy in the cloud), and ISO 27701 (privacy information management).

name: SOC 2 (System and Organization Controls)
description: SOC 2 is an audit standard for service organizations evaluating controls related to Security, Availability, Processing Integrity, Confidentiality, and Privacy. A SOC 2 Type II audit is often required in vendor due diligence, particularly for cloud and SaaS providers.

name: NIST Cybersecurity Framework (CSF)
description: The NIST Cybersecurity Framework (CSF) is a voluntary framework for managing cybersecurity risk, structured around Identify, Protect, Detect, Respond, and Recover functions. It is widely adopted internationally as a best practice baseline, even if not mandated in all sectors.

name: Center for Internet Security (CIS) Controls
description: The CIS Controls are a prioritized list of 18 cybersecurity best practices, often used to harden systems. These controls are widely adopted by organizations to improve cybersecurity posture.

name: OWASP Top 10
description: The OWASP Top 10 is a list of the top 10 web application security risks, published by the Open Web Application Security Project. While not a compliance framework, it serves as a checklist for developers to avoid common vulnerabilities in web applications.

name: CSA STAR / CAIQ
description: The Cloud Security Alliance (CSA) STAR certification is designed for cloud providers, and the Consensus Assessments Initiative Questionnaire (CAIQ) is a detailed survey mapping a provider’s security controls to CSA’s Cloud Controls Matrix. It is widely used in cloud security assessments.

name: Shared Assessments SIG (Standardized Information Gathering)
description: The Shared Assessments SIG is a comprehensive third-party risk assessment questionnaire covering 18 risk domains, including information security, privacy, and business continuity. It is commonly used by organizations to assess the security and compliance of their vendors.

name: ITIL / COBIT
description: ITIL (Information Technology Infrastructure Library) is a framework for IT service management, and COBIT (Control Objectives for Information and Related Technologies) is a framework for IT governance. Both are often referenced in compliance and IT process questionnaires.

name: BSI IT-Grundschutz
description: BSI IT-Grundschutz is a German national standard for information security. It is often used by organizations working with the German government and is similar to ISO 27001, focusing on risk management and protection of IT systems.

name: ISO 14001
description: ISO 14001 is an international standard for environmental management systems (EMS). It helps organizations improve their environmental performance by managing resources and reducing waste.

name: ISO 45001
description: ISO 45001 is a global standard for occupational health and safety management systems. It provides a framework to improve employee safety, reduce workplace risks, and create better, safer working conditions.

name: GHC Protocol
description: The GHG (Greenhouse Gas) Protocol provides a comprehensive global standard for measuring and managing greenhouse gas emissions. It is widely used by organizations for sustainability and climate impact reporting.

name: Trust and Transparency Initiatives
description: Many companies maintain Trust Centers or similar web portals where they publish certifications, policies, audit reports, and other compliance-related information to improve transparency with customers.

name: GDPR (General Data Protection Regulation)
description: GDPR is a comprehensive regulation that standardizes data protection laws across the EU, giving individuals extensive rights over their personal data, including access, erasure, and portability. It enforces strict consent requirements, mandatory breach notifications, and potential fines of up to 4% of global revenue for violations. The regulation also has extraterritorial reach.

name: UK GDPR & Data Protection Act 2018
description: The UK's adaptation of GDPR principles following Brexit. It retains the same protections and requirements as EU GDPR but establishes the UK's independent data protection framework. It includes provisions for law enforcement and intelligence services data processing.

name: PDPA (Personal Data Protection Act)
description: The PDPA in Singapore governs the collection, use, disclosure, and care of personal data by organizations through a consent-based framework. It requires organizations to appoint Data Protection Officers and includes provisions for breach notifications and data portability.

name: PIPL (Personal Information Protection Law)
description: PIPL is China's first comprehensive personal information protection law, enforcing strict rules on data processing activities, including localization requirements and mandatory security assessments for cross-border data transfers. Violations can result in severe penalties, including business suspension and personal liability for executives.

name: DPDP Act (Digital Personal Data Protection Act)
description: The DPDP Act in India is a newly enacted data protection law focusing on digital personal data. It introduces data fiduciary responsibilities, legitimate use requirements, and a Data Protection Board. The Act also includes provisions for cross-border data flows and penalties for violations.

name: LGPD (Lei Geral de Proteção de Dados)
description: LGPD is Brazil's General Data Protection Law, closely following GDPR’s model, with provisions for ten legal bases for data processing, data subject rights, and the appointment of Data Protection Officers. Violations may result in sanctions, including fines of up to 2% of Brazilian revenue.

name: PDPO (Personal Data (Privacy) Ordinance)
description: The PDPO is Hong Kong's privacy law that establishes six data protection principles. Recently, the law has been strengthened with anti-doxxing provisions. The Privacy Commissioner has enforcement powers for compliance and investigation.

name: Privacy Act (Australia)
description: The Privacy Act in Australia is a foundational privacy law containing 13 Australian Privacy Principles. It governs the handling of personal information by government agencies and larger businesses. The law is enforced by the Office of the Australian Information Commissioner.

name: Personal Information Protection Acts (Asia)
description: Several Asian nations have strong privacy frameworks. For example, South Korea's PIPA is one of Asia’s strictest laws, Thailand’s PDPA is GDPR-like with extraterritorial application, and Japan’s APPI recently strengthened international transfer restrictions.

name: FATF Recommendations
description: The Financial Action Task Force (FATF) Recommendations comprise 40 international standards that serve as the global benchmark for anti-money laundering (AML) and counter-terrorist financing (CFT) measures. These recommendations require countries to implement risk-based approaches, conduct enhanced customer due diligence, maintain transaction monitoring systems, and establish Financial Intelligence Units for suspicious transaction analysis.

name: Bank Secrecy Act (BSA)
description: The Bank Secrecy Act (BSA) is the cornerstone of U.S. anti-money laundering (AML) legislation. It requires financial institutions to implement robust AML compliance programs including customer identification procedures, transaction monitoring, and filing of Currency Transaction Reports for transactions exceeding $10,000. The USA PATRIOT Act complements the BSA with enhanced due diligence requirements.

name: EU Anti-Money Laundering Directives (4th, 5th, 6th)
description: The EU Anti-Money Laundering Directives (4th, 5th, and 6th) strengthen AML controls across the European Union. The 4th Directive introduced risk assessments and beneficial ownership registers, the 5th extended regulations to virtual currencies and prepaid cards, and the 6th harmonized money laundering criminal offenses and established minimum imprisonment penalties.

name: Proceeds of Crime Act (UK)
description: The Proceeds of Crime Act (POCA) is a UK law that criminalizes money laundering activities such as concealing, arranging, and acquiring criminal property. It requires regulated sectors to report suspicious activity and grants authorities powers for civil recovery, cash seizure, and confiscation of criminal assets.

name: PCMLTFA (Proceeds of Crime (Money Laundering) and Terrorist Financing Act)
description: The PCMLTFA establishes Canada's AML and CFT regime, requiring reporting entities to implement compliance programs, conduct customer identification, maintain records, and report suspicious and large cash transactions to FINTRAC. Recent amendments extend coverage to virtual currency exchanges and foreign money services businesses operating in Canada.

name: Regional AML Laws (Asia-Pacific)
description: Major Asian and Pacific jurisdictions have developed comprehensive AML frameworks. These include China’s Anti-Money Laundering Law, Hong Kong’s AMLO, Singapore’s Corruption, Drug Trafficking and Other Serious Crimes Act, Japan’s Act on Prevention of Transfer of Criminal Proceeds, India’s Prevention of Money Laundering Act, and Australia’s AML/CTF Act with a risk-based approach.
jurisdiction: China, Hong Kong, Singapore, Japan, India, Australia

name: FCPA (Foreign Corrupt Practices Act)
description: The FCPA prohibits payments to foreign government officials to obtain business advantages and mandates publicly-traded companies to maintain accurate books and records with effective internal accounting controls. Enforced by the DOJ and SEC with extraterritorial jurisdiction and penalties including criminal fines up to $2 million per violation for corporations, imprisonment for individuals, and disgorgement of profits.

name: UK Bribery Act
description: The UK Bribery Act is considered one of the world’s strictest anti-corruption laws. It creates offenses for bribing another person, receiving bribes, bribing foreign public officials, and failing to prevent bribery within organizations. It applies to both public and private sectors and imposes strict liability for organizations without adequate prevention procedures, with unlimited fines and up to 10 years imprisonment.

name: OECD Anti-Bribery Convention
description: The OECD Anti-Bribery Convention requires signatory countries to criminalize bribery of foreign public officials in international business transactions. It includes mutual legal assistance, corporate liability, and peer review mechanisms to monitor effective implementation across countries.

name: UNCAC (United Nations Convention Against Corruption)
description: The UNCAC is the only legally binding universal anti-corruption instrument with 189 parties. It establishes global standards for the prevention, criminalization, and cooperation against corruption. It covers public and private sector corruption and provides frameworks for asset recovery and international cooperation.

name: European National Laws
description: European anti-corruption laws include France’s Sapin II, which requires corporate compliance programs with fines up to €1 million for companies, and Germany's Criminal Code, which criminalizes bribery and includes provisions for corporate liability and confiscation of proceeds.

name: CFPOA (Corruption of Foreign Public Officials Act)
description: The CFPOA criminalizes bribing foreign public officials in business transactions. Penalties include unlimited fines for corporations and up to 14 years imprisonment for individuals. Recent amendments removed facilitation payment exceptions and created a separate offense for failure to maintain accurate books and records.

name: Asia-Pacific Anti-Corruption Laws
description: Asia-Pacific jurisdictions have developed diverse anti-corruption frameworks. These include China’s Criminal Law, India’s Prevention of Corruption Act, Singapore’s Prevention of Corruption Act, Japan’s Unfair Competition Prevention Act, and South Korea’s Improper Solicitation and Graft Act, which criminalize bribery and corruption, with severe penalties and jurisdictional reach.
jurisdiction: China, India, Singapore, Japan, South Korea

name: FATF Recommendations 24 & 25
description: FATF Recommendations 24 and 25 mandate that jurisdictions ensure transparency regarding the beneficial ownership of legal persons and arrangements. Countries must maintain accurate, timely information on beneficial ownership, accessible to competent authorities. The 2022 revisions require a multi-pronged approach including central registries, record maintenance by legal entities, and stronger verification mechanisms to combat shell companies.

name: Corporate Transparency Act (US)
description: The Corporate Transparency Act, enacted in 2021, requires certain companies in the U.S. to report beneficial ownership information to FinCEN. This includes details on individuals who own 25% or more of equity interest or have substantial control. Non-compliance results in fines up to $10,000 and imprisonment up to two years for willful violations.

name: EU Anti-Money Laundering Directives
description: The EU Anti-Money Laundering Directives progressively strengthened beneficial ownership transparency. The 4th AMLD introduced central registers; the 5th AMLD expanded public access to these registers and interconnected them across member states; and the 6th AMLD reinforced verification requirements for the 25% ownership threshold.

name: UK People with Significant Control Register
description: The UK People with Significant Control Register requires companies to identify and report individuals with significant control to Companies House. Control is defined through ownership of more than 25% of shares/voting rights, or the power to influence directors. Non-compliance can result in criminal penalties.

name: Register of Overseas Entities (UK)
description: The Register of Overseas Entities requires foreign companies owning UK property to declare their beneficial owners to Companies House. This initiative was established under the Economic Crime (Transparency and Enforcement) Act 2022. Non-compliance can lead to fines, imprisonment, and restrictions on property transactions.

name: Regional Ownership Transparency Laws
description: Various jurisdictions in the Asia-Pacific and North America have implemented beneficial ownership transparency laws. These include Singapore's Register of Controllers, Hong Kong's Significant Controllers Register, Canada's CBCA amendments, and Australia's proposed beneficial ownership register. These frameworks enhance transparency regarding individuals with significant interest or control in corporate entities.

name: UN Security Council Sanctions
description: Global sanctions regime under Chapter VII of the UN Charter, binding on all 193 member states. Measures include asset freezes, travel bans, and sectoral restrictions targeting counterterrorism, non-proliferation, and regional conflicts. Sanctions are implemented through Security Council Resolutions with compliance monitored by sanctions committees.

name: EU Sanctions
description: Comprehensive sanctions framework implementing UN measures and EU-specific sanctions. Measures include asset freezes, travel restrictions, sectoral sanctions (energy, finance, defense), and thematic sanctions addressing human rights violations and cyber-attacks. Enforced through regulations, requiring unanimous EU Council decisions.

name: OFAC (US)
description: The Office of Foreign Assets Control administers a comprehensive sanctions regime globally, impacting the US financial system. Maintains multiple lists including SDN (Specially Designated Nationals) and Sectoral Sanctions. Violations carry civil penalties up to $1.1 million per transaction, with criminal penalties including imprisonment.

name: UK Sanctions
description: The UK’s post-Brexit sanctions regime under the Sanctions and Anti-Money Laundering Act 2018. Includes asset freezes and UK-specific measures administered by OFSI. Penalties include civil fines up to £1 million or 50% of the breach value, and criminal penalties including imprisonment for up to 7 years.

name: PEP Screening Requirements
description: FATF Recommendation 12 requires enhanced due diligence for politically exposed persons (PEPs), including their family members and close associates. Requires identification, source of wealth verification, and ongoing monitoring. Varying definitions and risk tiers are implemented by different jurisdictions.

name: Regional Sanctions Regimes
description: Various jurisdictions maintain independent sanctions frameworks, including Canada's Special Economic Measures Act (penalties up to $25,000 and 5 years imprisonment), Australia's autonomous sanctions, and Japan's Foreign Exchange and Foreign Trade Act. These align with but are not identical to UN, US, and EU sanctions.

name: Screening and Compliance Practices
description: Financial institutions and designated non-financial businesses must screen transactions and customers against sanctions lists, PEP databases, and adverse media. This includes real-time transaction screening, periodic rescreening, and manual review processes, with layered approaches combining automated and manual procedures.

name: Export Administration Regulations (US)
description: Regulations administered by the Bureau of Industry and Security (BIS) that control the export, reexport, and transfer of commercial and dual-use items based on the Commerce Control List (CCL). Includes a complex license requirement system based on item classification, destination countries, and end-users. Targets emerging technologies and countries like China and Russia.

name: International Traffic in Arms Regulations (US)
description: Regulations by the US State Department governing defense articles, technical data, and defense services listed on the United States Munitions List (USML). Requires registration with DDTC and licensing for exports. Violations incur penalties up to $1 million per violation and 20 years imprisonment.

name: EU Dual-Use Regulation
description: EU regulation 2021/821 establishing a regime for controlling exports, brokering, transit, and transfer of dual-use items. Based on international regimes such as the Wassenaar Arrangement, it requires common authorization for items with specific controls, including cyber-surveillance technologies and Internal Compliance Programs (ICPs).

name: UK Export Control Order
description: Post-Brexit export control regime under the Export Control Order 2008. Manages military and dual-use controls, administered by the Export Control Joint Unit (ECJU). Features controls on software, technology transfers, and academic research, especially regarding intangible transfers (ITT) via electronic means.

name: Regional Export Controls
description: Export control regimes maintained by major trading nations, such as China's Export Control Law (2020), Japan's Foreign Exchange and Foreign Trade Act, Singapore's Strategic Goods Control Act, and South Korea's Foreign Trade Act. These include extraterritorial jurisdiction and controls on sensitive technologies with a focus on regional security concerns.

name: Anti-Boycott Regulations
description: US regulations prohibiting participation in unsanctioned foreign boycotts, particularly the Arab League boycott of Israel. Includes reporting requirements and prohibits providing boycott-related information. Civil and criminal penalties are imposed for violations.

name: Customs and Import Regulations
description: Compliance requirements for customs including proper Harmonized Tariff Schedule (HTS) classification, country-of-origin determination, and compliance with Free Trade Agreements. Violations can result in civil penalties, detention or seizure of goods, and criminal prosecution under false statement statutes.

name: GDPR Chapter V
description: Framework prohibiting transfers of personal data outside the European Economic Area (EEA) unless appropriate safeguards are in place or specific derogations apply. Features a tiered approach prioritizing adequacy decisions, safeguards (SCCs, BCRs), and specific derogations. Following the Schrems II decision, it requires transfer impact assessments and supplementary measures against third-country surveillance laws.

name: EU Standard Contractual Clauses
description: Commission-approved templates that ensure GDPR-equivalent protection for data transfers between data exporters and importers. The 2021 modernized SCCs feature modular approaches for various transfer scenarios and include Schrems II requirements for local law assessments and technical measures.

name: EU-US Data Privacy Framework
description: An executive order-based framework for EU-US data transfers, replacing the invalidated Privacy Shield. It provides enhanced privacy protections, redress mechanisms, and safeguards against US intelligence collection. EU adequacy decision granted in 2023, though facing legal challenges on surveillance limitations.

name: Chinese PIPL Cross-Border Provisions
description: China's Personal Information Protection Law (PIPL) mandates security assessments, certification by institutions, or signing standard contracts for personal information transfers. Includes localization requirements for critical information infrastructure operators and large-volume data processors.

name: Russian Data Localization Law
description: Federal Law No. 242-FZ mandates that personal data of Russian citizens be stored and processed in databases physically located in Russia. Violations result in penalties including website blocking and fines, with enforcement by Roskomnadzor.

name: Indian Cross-Border Requirements
description: India's approach includes sector-specific regulations for financial data, requiring domestic storage of payment system data. The Digital Personal Data Protection Act of 2023 allows cross-border transfers to notified countries while granting the government powers to restrict transfers to specific countries.

name: Vietnam Cybersecurity Law
description: Requires domestic and foreign service providers to store Vietnamese users' data within Vietnam, covering personal data, service user relationships, and data generated within the country. Violations can result in service suspension and license revocation.

name: Regional Data Localization Requirements
description: Various approaches across Asia-Pacific, including Indonesia's regulation on domestic data centers, South Korea's sector-specific restrictions, Japan's consent-based transfers, Australia's health data requirements, Brazil's LGPD, and Saudi Arabia's cloud computing regulations for foreign data storage.

name: HIPAA (Health Insurance Portability and Accountability Act)
description: Establishes comprehensive requirements for protected health information, with Privacy, Security, and Breach Notification Rules. Enforced by OCR, with penalties up to $1.5 million per violation category. The HITECH Act strengthened HIPAA enforcement and expanded requirements to business associates.

name: HITECH Act
description: Strengthens HIPAA enforcement and extends requirements to business associates in the healthcare industry. Also addresses electronic health records and includes provisions to incentivize the adoption of health information technology.

name: 21 CFR Part 11
description: Governs electronic records and signatures in FDA-regulated environments. Requires validation, audit trails, and electronic signature controls.

name: EU Health Data Protections (GDPR Article 9)
description: Classifies health data as 'special category' requiring explicit consent or specific legal bases for processing under GDPR. The upcoming European Health Data Space (EHDS) regulation will facilitate secure health data sharing.

name: Medical Device Regulation (MDR) and In Vitro Diagnostic Regulation (IVDR)
description: Imposes strict cybersecurity requirements for medical devices and in vitro diagnostic devices to ensure their safe and secure use in healthcare environments.

name: Sarbanes-Oxley Act (SOX)
description: Mandates strict internal controls over financial reporting, including executive certification requirements and criminal penalties for violations.

name: Basel III/IV
description: Establishes international banking standards for capital adequacy, stress testing, and liquidity requirements to improve the banking sector's stability and resilience.

name: MiFID II (Markets in Financial Instruments Directive)
description: Regulates investment services across the EU, with extensive transaction reporting and best execution requirements to ensure investor protection and market transparency.

name: PSD2 (Payment Services Directive 2)
description: Opens the EU banking market to non-bank payment service providers with strong customer authentication requirements to enhance security and consumer protection in payments.

name: PCI-DSS (Payment Card Industry Data Security Standard)
description: Establishes security standards for payment card transactions with six major objectives including maintaining secure networks, protecting cardholder data, and regular testing. Enforced through merchant and service provider contracts.

name: AML/KYC Regulations
description: Requires financial institutions to identify customers, monitor transactions, and report suspicious activities to prevent money laundering and financing of terrorism.

name: FERPA (Family Educational Rights and Privacy Act)
description: Protects student educational records in US federally-funded institutions by requiring parental consent for disclosure, with rights transferring to students at age 18.

name: COPPA (Children's Online Privacy Protection Act)
description: Regulates the collection of personal information from children under 13, requiring parental consent and privacy notices.

name: State Student Privacy Laws (e.g., SOPIPA)
description: Prohibit targeted advertising, profiling, and the sale of student information. Examples include California's SOPIPA and the Student Online Personal Information Protection Act.

name: UK Age Appropriate Design Code
description: Imposes additional privacy requirements for services likely to be accessed by children, focusing on data minimization and privacy-by-default settings.

name: FedRAMP (Federal Risk and Authorization Management Program)
description: Standardizes cloud security assessments and authorizations across US federal agencies, with tiered impact levels (Low, Moderate, High) and continuous monitoring requirements.

name: NIST SP 800-171
description: Governs the protection of Controlled Unclassified Information (CUI) in non-federal systems with 14 security requirement families.

name: Cybersecurity Maturity Model Certification (CMMC)
description: Establishes five progressive maturity levels for defense contractors handling Federal Contract Information (FCI) and Controlled Unclassified Information (CUI), with specific cybersecurity controls.

name: NERC CIP (Critical Infrastructure Protection)
description: Establishes mandatory cybersecurity requirements for bulk electric system operators, including controls for electronic security perimeters, systems security management, and incident reporting.

name: EPA Risk Management Program
description: Imposes environmental reporting requirements and safety measures for chemical facilities to prevent and mitigate potential hazards.

name: SASB (Sustainability Accounting Standards Board) Energy Sector Metrics
description: Provides ESG (Environmental, Social, Governance) metrics for the energy sector, focusing on sustainability and climate-related risks.

name: TCFD (Task Force on Climate-related Financial Disclosures)
description: A reporting framework for climate risks in financial disclosures, focusing on energy and environment-related risks and opportunities.

name: EU Taxonomy Regulation
description: Establishes technical screening criteria for sustainable energy activities to determine which activities can be classified as environmentally sustainable.

name: Carbon Disclosure Project (CDP) Energy Sector Reporting Protocols
description: Provides reporting protocols for the energy sector on climate change, water security, and forest management.

name: ISO/IEC 27001
description: Internationally recognized standard specifying requirements for establishing, implementing, maintaining, and continually improving an Information Security Management System (ISMS). Built around a risk-based approach with 114 controls across 14 domains, including access control, cryptography, and supplier relationships.

name: SOC 2
description: AICPA framework for service organizations to demonstrate controls over information security, availability, processing integrity, confidentiality, and privacy. Reports include Type 1 (control design assessment) and Type 2 (testing of operational effectiveness).

name: NIST Cybersecurity Framework
description: A voluntary, risk-based approach organizing cybersecurity activities into five core functions: Identify, Protect, Detect, Respond, and Recover. It features implementation tiers and detailed control profiles, cross-referencing other standards like NIST SP 800-53 and ISO 27001.

name: CIS Controls
description: A prioritized set of cybersecurity best practices developed by the Center for Internet Security. Organized into three implementation groups, with 18 control categories that emphasize fundamental security hygiene, from inventory management to advanced organizational measures.

name: OWASP Top 10
description: Consensus-driven document identifying the top 10 most critical web application security risks. Updated periodically, the list includes risks such as broken access control, cryptographic failures, and injection attacks, serving as a baseline for web application security.

name: CSA STAR / CAIQ
description: Cloud Security Alliance's Security Trust Assurance and Risk (STAR) program offering standardized assessment and certification of cloud provider security. The CAIQ contains over 250 questions aligned with CSA's Cloud Controls Matrix (CCM) across 17 control domains.

name: Shared Assessments SIG
description: A comprehensive third-party risk assessment framework with over 1,000 questions across 18 risk domains including data security, privacy, and business resilience. SIG Core is used for general assessments, while SIG Lite is for lower-risk relationships.

name: PCI-DSS
description: Comprehensive requirements for entities handling cardholder data, with 12 requirements covering network security, data protection, vulnerability management, access control, and monitoring. Compliance validation varies by merchant level.

name: EU AI Act
description: The EU AI Act is the first comprehensive legal framework for AI, using a risk-based approach to categorize AI systems (unacceptable risk, high risk, limited risk, minimal risk), with corresponding requirements for transparency, human oversight, risk management, and documentation. Applies to all AI systems used or placing outputs on the market in the EU.

name: NIST AI Risk Management Framework
description: A voluntary framework developed by NIST that provides organizations with a structured approach to identifying, assessing, and managing risks associated with AI systems throughout their lifecycle. Focuses on trustworthiness and responsible AI development.

name: Singapore Model AI Governance Framework
description: A practical guidance framework developed by Singapore's Personal Data Protection Commission to help organizations implement responsible AI governance practices. Includes addressing internal governance structures, determining AI decision-making models, and managing operations of AI systems.

name: IEEE P7000 Series
description: A collection of ethical standards developed by IEEE addressing various aspects of AI systems, including data privacy, algorithmic bias, children's data rights, and transparency requirements to promote responsible and trustworthy AI development.

name: ISO/IEC 42001
description: International standard for AI management systems that provides requirements for establishing, implementing, maintaining, and continually improving an organization's AI management system, focusing on ethical considerations and risk management.

name: OECD AI Principles
description: A set of intergovernmental policy guidelines developed by the OECD that promote AI innovation while ensuring respect for human rights, democratic values, transparency, technical robustness, and accountability.

name: China's Algorithmic Recommendation Regulations
description: A regulatory framework introduced by the Cyberspace Administration of China that imposes specific requirements for automated decision-making systems and algorithmic recommendations. Includes user opt-out options, transparency in content selection, and protection against discrimination.

name: Canada's Artificial Intelligence and Data Act
description: A legislative framework establishing requirements for high-impact AI systems, including risk assessment, mitigation measures, monitoring for harmful outcomes, and transparency requirements. Focuses on protecting Canadians from potential AI harms while fostering innovation.

name: Digital Services Act/Digital Markets Act
description: A comprehensive EU regulatory framework aimed at creating a safer digital space and establishing a level playing field for digital services. The DSA imposes obligations on online platforms regarding content moderation, transparency, and user protection, while the DMA targets large 'gatekeeper' tech companies with additional requirements to ensure fair competition in digital markets.

name: DORA (Digital Operational Resilience Act)
description: The Digital Operational Resilience Act (DORA) establishes uniform requirements for the security of network and information systems of financial entities in the EU. It requires financial institutions to implement comprehensive ICT risk management frameworks, report major incidents, and conduct regular testing of digital operational resilience.

name: NIS2 Directive
description: An enhanced version of the Network and Information Security Directive, the NIS2 Directive strengthens cybersecurity requirements across the EU, expanding its scope to additional sectors and imposing stricter compliance requirements, incident reporting obligations, and risk management measures for essential and important entities.

name: ePrivacy Regulation (proposed)
description: The proposed ePrivacy Regulation aims to replace the ePrivacy Directive (Cookie Law) to enhance privacy protection in electronic communications. It addresses issues such as cookie consent, metadata processing, and the confidentiality of communications. Designed to complement the GDPR with specific rules for digital communications.

name: Online Safety Laws
description: Various national regulations, including the UK Online Safety Bill, place legal responsibilities on online platforms to protect users from harmful content. This includes requirements for risk assessments, content moderation policies, and user protection measures. Similar frameworks are being developed in Australia, Canada, and other countries to address online harms.

name: Corporate Sustainability Reporting Directive (EU)
description: Enhanced EU framework that significantly expands environmental, social, and governance (ESG) reporting requirements for large companies and listed SMEs. It mandates detailed disclosures on sustainability matters following European Sustainability Reporting Standards, including environmental impact, social responsibility, and governance practices with double materiality assessment.

name: Modern Slavery Acts
description: National legislation requiring businesses of certain sizes to publish annual statements outlining steps taken to identify and address modern slavery risks in their operations and supply chains. The UK Modern Slavery Act (2015) and Australia's Modern Slavery Act (2018) aim to increase transparency and accountability regarding forced labor and human trafficking.

name: Supply Chain Due Diligence Laws
type: Human Rights and Environmental Due Diligence
description: Legislation mandating human rights and environmental due diligence throughout global supply chains. The German Supply Chain Act (Lieferkettensorgfaltspflichtengesetz) requires companies to identify and mitigate human rights risks in their supply chains, while the French Duty of Vigilance Law (Loi de Vigilance) requires large companies to establish vigilance plans to prevent human rights violations and environmental damage.

name: Climate-related Financial Disclosures
description: Based on Task Force on Climate-related Financial Disclosures (TCFD) recommendations, these requirements focus on how organizations assess and manage climate-related risks and opportunities. Initially voluntary, TCFD-aligned disclosures are becoming mandatory in jurisdictions including the UK, New Zealand, Singapore, and Switzerland, requiring companies to report on governance, strategy, risk management, and metrics related to climate change.
